hero.title: Dependency Security Health

installation.title: Installation
installation.description: Install globally via npm or use npx to run without installation

liveReport.title: Live Demo
liveReport.subtitle: Example analysis of this landing page's dependencies
liveReport.description: This is a demonstration of the analysis output. The actual tool generates reports in multiple formats:

formats.cli: CLI - Beautiful colored terminal output with tables and summaries
formats.json: JSON - Structured data perfect for CI/CD pipelines and automation
formats.csv: CSV - Spreadsheet-friendly format for data analysis and tracking

liveReport.noteDescription: This table shows a simplified view of the landing page's dependencies. Run the tool in your own project to get a complete analysis with detailed recommendations, security insights, and customizable output formats.

documentation.title: Documentation
documentation.subtitle: Complete guide to using package-health-analyzer for dependency analysis and compliance

installation.title: Installation
installation.content: Install package-health-analyzer globally using npm or run it directly with npx. Global installation allows you to use the tool across all your projects, while npx is perfect for one-time analyses or CI/CD environments.

quickStart.title: Quick Start
quickStart.content: Navigate to your Node.js project directory and run the analyzer. The tool will automatically detect your package.json file, analyze all dependencies (including devDependencies), and generate a comprehensive health report with security insights, license compliance, and age analysis.

requirements.title: Requirements
requirements.content: Requires Node.js version 18 or higher and a valid package.json file with a dependencies section. For full functionality including vulnerability scanning and GitHub integration, ensure you have internet connectivity and optionally configure a GitHub token for enhanced API limits.

basicScan.title: Basic Scan
basicScan.content: Perform a basic dependency scan by running the analyzer in your project directory. This generates a CLI report showing package health scores, license information, age analysis, and basic security insights. The output is color-coded for easy identification of issues.

outputFormats.title: Output Formats
outputFormats.content: Export analysis results in multiple formats: CLI for terminal viewing with colors and tables, JSON for programmatic consumption and CI/CD integration, CSV for spreadsheet analysis and tracking, and SBOM for software bill of materials in SPDX 2.3 format compliant with federal standards.

advancedOptions.title: Advanced Options
advancedOptions.content: Customize your analysis with advanced flags: enable vulnerability scanning with --vulnerabilities, analyze transitive dependencies with --transitive, generate NOTICE.txt files with --notice, export SBOM with --sbom, configure output paths, set custom cache TTL, and filter dependencies by license or health score thresholds.

configuration.title: Configuration File
configuration.content: Create a .packagehealthanalyzerrc.json file in your project root to define default settings, license policies, security thresholds, and output preferences. This allows consistent analysis across team members and CI/CD environments without needing to specify flags each time.

configFile.title: Configuration File Structure
configFile.content: The .packagehealthanalyzerrc.json file supports comprehensive configuration options including license policies, security thresholds, output formats, GitHub token encryption, cache settings, and custom scoring weights. All settings are optional and fall back to sensible defaults.

licensePolicies.title: License Policies
licensePolicies.content: Define custom license policies to enforce compliance with your organization's requirements. Configure allowed, warned, and blocked licenses, set commercial compatibility requirements, detect patent clauses, and create custom license classifications. The tool supports 221 SPDX licenses plus custom license identifiers.
licensePolicies.allowedLicenses: Licenses that are always accepted without warnings
licensePolicies.warnedLicenses: Licenses that trigger warnings but don't fail the build
licensePolicies.blockedLicenses: Licenses that are prohibited and will fail compliance checks
licensePolicies.commercialUse: Filter licenses by commercial compatibility (friendly, warning, or incompatible)
licensePolicies.patentClauses: Detect and flag licenses with patent termination clauses

securityThresholds.title: Security Thresholds
securityThresholds.content: Configure vulnerability scanning thresholds to control which security issues trigger warnings or failures. Set minimum severity levels (low, moderate, high, critical), maximum age for dependencies, minimum health scores, and custom scoring weights for different factors.

cicd.title: CI/CD Integration
cicd.content: Integrate package-health-analyzer into your continuous integration pipeline to automatically scan dependencies on every build. Use JSON output for parsing results, set exit codes based on security thresholds, cache results for faster builds, and generate SBOM artifacts for compliance tracking. Compatible with GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, Jenkins, and all major CI/CD platforms.

compliance.title: License Compliance
compliance.content: Ensure legal compliance by validating all dependencies against your organization's license policies. Generate NOTICE.txt files for Apache-style projects, export SBOM in SPDX 2.3 format for federal compliance (CISA SBOM 2025, NIST 800-161), detect patent clauses, identify GPL contamination risks, and maintain audit trails for legal review.

security.title: Security Auditing
security.content: Perform comprehensive security audits by scanning for known vulnerabilities via GitHub Advisory Database, detecting deprecated packages, analyzing dependency age and maintenance status, identifying transitive vulnerability propagation through 10 layers of dependencies, and tracking CVEs with severity classifications (low, moderate, high, critical).

maintenance.title: Dependency Maintenance
maintenance.content: Maintain healthy dependencies by regularly analyzing package age, identifying outdated dependencies with upgrade recommendations, detecting deprecated packages, monitoring GitHub repository health (stars, forks, last commit), analyzing maintenance status, and tracking dependency bloat with transitive dependency analysis.

github.title: GitHub Integration
github.content: Enhanced GitHub integration provides repository health metrics, star counts, fork counts, last commit dates, and maintenance status. Configure a GitHub personal access token to increase API rate limits from 60 to 5000 requests per hour. Tokens are encrypted using AES-256-GCM with secure memory cleanup and file permission validation (600).

npm.title: NPM Registry
npm.content: Automatically fetches package metadata from npm registry including version history, publish dates, maintainer information, download statistics, and license texts from npm CDN. Supports private registries and scoped packages. Results are cached with configurable TTL (default 1 hour) for improved performance.

cli.title: CLI Output
cli.content: Beautiful colored terminal output with formatted tables, dependency summaries, health scores, license classifications, vulnerability alerts, and actionable recommendations. Supports wide and compact modes, color customization, and ASCII-safe rendering for legacy terminals.

json.title: JSON Output
json.content: Structured JSON format perfect for programmatic consumption, CI/CD integration, and automated processing. Includes complete dependency metadata, vulnerability details, license information, health scores, transitive dependency trees with statistics (totalNodes, uniquePackages, maxDepth, circularDependencies, duplicatePackages), and processing timestamps. Schema is stable and versioned for reliable parsing.

csv.title: CSV Output
csv.content: Spreadsheet-friendly CSV format for data analysis, tracking, and reporting. Includes package name, version, license, age, health score, vulnerability count, GitHub metrics, and status flags. Compatible with Excel, Google Sheets, and all major spreadsheet applications. Supports custom column selection and ordering.

sbom.title: SBOM (SPDX)
sbom.content: Software Bill of Materials in SPDX 2.3 JSON format compliant with CISA SBOM 2025 minimum elements and NIST 800-161 supply chain requirements. Includes package identifiers, version information, supplier details, license declarations, checksums, external references, and dependency relationships. Required for federal government software procurement.

notice.title: NOTICE.txt
notice.content: Apache-style NOTICE.txt files for legal compliance and attribution. Includes full license texts fetched from npm CDN and GitHub repositories, copyright notices, attribution requirements, and disclaimer texts. Automatically handles multiple licenses, dual-licensing scenarios, and license exceptions. Essential for Apache Software Foundation projects and open source distributions.

sarif.title: SARIF (Static Analysis)
sarif.content: Static Analysis Results Interchange Format (SARIF) 2.1.0 for integration with GitHub Code Scanning, security platforms, and SIEM tools. Includes vulnerability findings with severity levels, license compliance issues, deprecated package warnings, and automated remediation suggestions. Compatible with GitHub Advanced Security, Azure DevOps, and other SARIF-aware tools.

commonIssues.title: Common Issues
commonIssues.content: Network connectivity: Ensure internet access for npm registry and GitHub API requests. Rate limiting: Configure GitHub token to increase API limits. Cache issues: Clear cache with --no-cache flag or delete .package-health-cache directory. Parsing errors: Verify package.json is valid JSON. Permission errors: Check file permissions for config files and output directories.

performance.title: Performance Optimization
performance.content: Improve analysis speed by enabling caching (default), using GitHub token to avoid rate limits, limiting transitive dependency depth, excluding devDependencies when not needed, running in CI/CD with cached node_modules, and using --no-vulnerabilities flag when security scanning is not required. Cached analyses complete in less than 1 second.

regular.title: Regular Analysis
regular.content: Run dependency health analysis regularly: before every release, weekly in development, daily in CI/CD pipelines, after adding new dependencies, and when security advisories are published. Automate analysis with scheduled CI/CD jobs and configure notifications for critical issues.

policies.title: License Policies
policies.content: Establish clear license policies: define allowed licenses for your organization, identify GPL and copyleft risks, require patent grant licenses for critical dependencies, maintain a blocklist of incompatible licenses, document exceptions and approvals, and review policies quarterly as license landscape evolves.

security.title: Security Hygiene
security.content: Maintain security hygiene: fix critical and high vulnerabilities immediately, update dependencies quarterly, monitor deprecation warnings, avoid packages with no recent maintenance, review transitive dependencies for hidden vulnerabilities, use SBOM for supply chain tracking, and maintain an incident response plan for zero-day vulnerabilities.

licenseModal.title: License Compliance Guide
licenseModal.howToUseDescription: This guide categorizes 221 SPDX licenses by commercial compatibility. Use it to configure your .packagehealthanalyzerrc.json file and ensure compliance with your organization's policies. Licenses are classified using Blue Oak Council ratings and commercial use analysis.

LGPL-2.1.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

LGPL-2.1-only.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1 only

LGPL-2.1-or-later.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1 or later

LGPL-3.0.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

LGPL-3.0-only.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0 only

LGPL-3.0-or-later.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0 or later

GPL-2.0-only.name: GNU General Public License v2.0 only

GPL-2.0-or-later.name: GNU General Public License v2.0 or later

GPL-3.0-only.name: GNU General Public License v3.0 only

GPL-3.0-or-later.name: GNU General Public License v3.0 or later

AGPL-3.0.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

AGPL-3.0-only.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0 only

AGPL-3.0-or-later.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0 or later

licenseModal.goldLicensesExpand: + Show all 47 Gold licenses (click to expand)
licenseModal.commercialFriendlyDescription: These licenses are permissive and suitable for commercial use without significant restrictions. They generally require attribution and disclaimer of warranty but allow proprietary derivatives.

commercialFriendlyList.MIT: MIT License - Most popular, simple and permissive
commercialFriendlyList.Apache-2.0: Apache License 2.0 - Includes patent grant and trademark protection
commercialFriendlyList.ISC: ISC License - Equivalent to MIT, simpler wording
commercialFriendlyList.0BSD: BSD Zero Clause - Most permissive, no conditions
commercialFriendlyList.CC0-1.0: Creative Commons Zero - Public domain waiver
commercialFriendlyList.Zlib: zlib License - Permissive for software libraries
commercialFriendlyList.BlueOak-1.0.0: Blue Oak Model License - Modern permissive license
commercialFriendlyList.MIT-0: MIT No Attribution - MIT without attribution requirement
commercialFriendlyList.UPL-1.0: Universal Permissive License - Oracle's permissive license
commercialFriendlyList.WTFPL: Do What The F*ck You Want To Public License
commercialFriendlyList.MPL-2.0: Mozilla Public License 2.0 - Weak copyleft, file-level
commercialFriendlyList.LGPL-3.0: GNU Lesser GPL 3.0 - Updated LGPL with patent provisions
commercialFriendlyList.NCSA: University of Illinois/NCSA Open Source License
commercialFriendlyList.Unicode-DFS-2016: Unicode Data Files and Software License

licenseModal.commercialWarningDescription: These licenses have specific restrictions or requirements that need careful review before commercial use. They may include patent termination clauses, copyleft requirements, or commercial use limitations.

commercialWarningList.Elastic-2.0: Elastic License 2.0 - Prohibits providing software as a service
commercialWarningList.SSPL-1.0: Server Side Public License - Strong copyleft for SaaS
commercialWarningList.BUSL-1.1: Business Source License - Converts to open source after time period
commercialWarningList.CC-BY-4.0: Creative Commons Attribution - Primarily for creative works, not software
commercialWarningList.CC-BY-NC-4.0: Creative Commons Non-Commercial - Prohibits commercial use
commercialWarningList.AGPL-3.0: GNU Affero GPL 3.0 - Network copyleft, see incompatible section
commercialWarningList.GPL-2.0: GNU GPL 2.0 - Strong copyleft, see incompatible section
commercialWarningList.GPL-3.0: GNU GPL 3.0 - Strong copyleft with patent provisions
commercialWarningList.LGPL-2.1-only: LGPL 2.1 only - No later versions allowed
commercialWarningList.LGPL-3.0-only: LGPL 3.0 only - No later versions allowed

licenseModal.commercialIncompatibleDescription: These licenses are generally incompatible with commercial proprietary software due to strong copyleft requirements, non-commercial restrictions, or other limitations. Using these licenses typically requires releasing your entire codebase under the same license.

commercialIncompatibleList.GPL-3.0-only: GNU GPL 3.0 only - Strong copyleft with patents
commercialIncompatibleList.CPOL-1.02: Code Project Open License - Custom restrictions
commercialIncompatibleList.NPL-1.1: Netscape Public License - Deprecated, use MPL
commercialIncompatibleList.OLDAP-2.8: Open LDAP Public License - Specific to OpenLDAP
commercialIncompatibleList.QPL-1.0: Q Public License - Unusual distribution requirements
commercialIncompatibleList.SISSL: Sun Industry Standards Source License - Deprecated
commercialIncompatibleList.ODbL-1.0: Open Data Commons Open Database License
commercialIncompatibleList.CECILL-2.1: CEA CNRS INRIA Logiciel Libre - French GPL equivalent

licenseModal.configurationExamplesDescription: Use these examples to configure license policies in your .packagehealthanalyzerrc.json file. Customize the lists based on your organization's requirements and legal counsel recommendations.
licenseModal.configExample1Description: Only allow highly permissive licenses, block all copyleft
licenseModal.configExample2Description: Allow weak copyleft (MPL, LGPL) but block strong copyleft
licenseModal.configExample3Description: Allow most licenses except non-commercial and deprecated
licenseModal.quickTip1: Always consult legal counsel for license compliance in commercial products
licenseModal.quickTip2: MIT, Apache-2.0, and BSD licenses are safe for most commercial use cases
licenseModal.quickTip3: GPL and AGPL licenses require releasing your entire codebase under the same license
licenseModal.quickTip4: LGPL can be used in commercial software if dynamically linked (library)
licenseModal.quickTip5: Watch for Elastic-2.0 and SSPL-1.0 in infrastructure dependencies - they prohibit SaaS
licenseModal.quickTip6: Creative Commons licenses (CC-*) are for creative works, not software code
licenseModal.quickTip7: The --notice flag generates NOTICE.txt with all license texts for distribution
licenseModal.quickTip8: Use --sbom to generate SPDX 2.3 software bill of materials for compliance tracking
